title: Quiz 2: Planning a Community Diagnosis
description: Evaluate your knowledge on community exploration, obtaining permission, and logistical planning for a survey.

questions.question: Which of the following activities are part of the 'Exploration' (Community Inventory) phase?
questions.explanation: Exploration involves permission, reactions, and background data. Analysis and reporting happen after the survey is executed.
questions.hint: Think about what needs to happen BEFORE the actual survey begins.

questions.question: Order the hierarchy for seeking permission to enter a community:

items.text: Medical Officer in Charge / Health Personnel

questions.explanation: Protocol typically flows from the highest administrative/health authority down to local leaders and then the public.
questions.hint: Start with the official administration and move down to the village level.

questions.question: You should plan a survey even if you have no intention of carrying out an action program for the community.
questions.explanation: If the community gives permission, they have a right to expect beneficial results. You should always plan with the intention of carrying out an action program.
questions.hint: Is it ethical to take data without giving back?

questions.question: When planning 'When' the survey will take place, which timing should be AVOIDED?

options.text: Days when the health center is open

questions.explanation: You should avoid days when people are less likely to be at home, such as market days, or during heavy activity like planting seasons.
questions.hint: When are people least likely to be found at home?

questions.question: What are the desirable qualities of a survey interviewer?

options.text: Literate and well known to the community
Speak the language of the study group

questions.explanation: Interviewers need to be literate, socially skilled (rapport, listening), and culturally/linguistically compatible with the community.
questions.hint: Think about who you would trust to come into your home and ask questions.

questions.question: Match the planning question to its rationale:

pairs.right: To justify the survey to leaders and ensure community benefit.
To determine the sample size and selection method.
To avoid market days and busy seasons.
To identify resources, interviewers, and time needed.

questions.explanation: Why = Justification; Who = Sampling; When = Timing/Availability; How = Logistics/Resources.
questions.hint: Connect the question word to the logical planning step.

questions.question: Ideally, interviewers should come from the ___BLANK___ so that they are well known to its members.
questions.explanation: Using local interviewers builds trust and ensures they know the area and people.
questions.hint: The group of people being studied.

questions.question: What is the term for 'mapping out a community to learn or discover about it'?
questions.explanation: Exploration involves mapping out the community, also known as Community Inventory.

questions.question: Why should you hold a public meeting before the survey begins?

options.text: To explain the survey's purpose and introduce the team to the community.

questions.explanation: A meeting clarifies why the survey is happening, who is involved, and what will happen, ensuring community cooperation.

questions.question: Interviewers do not need any training if they are already literate; they can just read the questions.
questions.explanation: Interviewers MUST be trained to ensure they understand the purpose, record answers consistently, and follow procedures.
questions.hint: Is reading enough to conduct a scientific survey?
